Ordinary Least Squares Some example R code we want to solve something of the form \[ \boldsymbol{Y} = \boldsymbol{X}\boldsymbol{\beta} + \boldsymbol{\epsilon} \] OLS is typically learned as \[ (\boldsymbol{X}'\boldsymbol{X})^{-1}\boldsymbol{X}'\boldsymbol{Y} \] - but in practice, this is computationally inefficient - floating point algebra, matrix inversion, etc etc - instead, we use QR decomposition \[ \boldsymbol{X} = \boldsymbol{QR} \] - since R is an upper triangular matrix, we can set \[ \boldsymbol{Y} = \boldsymbol{QR}\boldsymbol{\beta} \] - meaning that: \[ \boldsymbol{Q}^{-1}\boldsymbol{Y} = \boldsymbol{R}\boldsymbol{\beta} \] - by definition of the QR decomposition: \[ \boldsymbol{Q}^{-1}\boldsymbol{Y} = \boldsymbol{Q}'\boldsymbol{Y}\] - we can therefore exploit the triangular structur of \(\boldsymbol{R}\) to backsolve the equation: \[ \boldsymbol{Q}'\boldsymbol{Y} = \boldsymbol{R}\boldsymbol{\beta} \] set.seed(42) N <- 1000 X1 = rnorm(N) X2 = rnorm(N) y = 1.5 + 2*X1 + 3*X2 + rnorm(N) df <- data.frame( y, X1, X2 ) f <- y ~ X1 + X2 ols <- function(data, formula, method="QR", na.action=na.exclude) { mf <- model.frame(formula, data, na.action=na.action) Y <- model.response(mf, type="double") X <- model.matrix(mf) if (method == "matrix") B <- solve(t(X) %*% X) %*% t(X) %*% Y if (method == "QR") { QR <- qr(X) Q <- qr.Q(QR) R <- qr.R(QR) B <- backsolve(R, t(Q)%*%Y) } return(B) } ols(df, f) ## [,1] ## [1,] 1.496133 ## [2,] 1.978201 ## [3,] 2.981712 ols(df, f, "matrix") ## [,1] ## (Intercept) 1.496133 ## X1 1.978201 ## X2 2.981712 summary(lm(f, df)) ## ## Call: ## lm(formula = f, data = df) ## ## Residuals: ## Min 1Q Median 3Q Max ## -3.1968 -0.6336 0.0163 0.6654 3.4847 ## ## Coefficients: ## Estimate Std.
